trans-unit.source: Using .NET Core SDK and tools in Continuous Integration (CI)
trans-unit.target: Using .NET Core SDK and tools in Continuous Integration (CI)

trans-unit.source: Using .NET Core SDK and tools in Continuous Integration (CI)
trans-unit.target: Using .NET Core SDK and tools in Continuous Integration (CI)

trans-unit.source: .NET, .NET Core
trans-unit.target: .NET, .NET Core

trans-unit.source: Using .NET Core SDK and tools in Continuous Integration (CI)
trans-unit.target: Using .NET Core SDK and tools in Continuous Integration (CI)

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This document outlines the usage of .NET Core SDK and its tools on the build server.
trans-unit.target: This document outlines the usage of .NET Core SDK and its tools on the build server.

trans-unit.source: In general, on a CI build server, you want to automate the installation in some way.
trans-unit.target: In general, on a CI build server, you want to automate the installation in some way.

trans-unit.source: The automation, ideally, should not require administrative privileges if at all possible.
trans-unit.target: The automation, ideally, should not require administrative privileges if at all possible.

trans-unit.source: For SaaS CI solutions, there are several options.
trans-unit.target: For SaaS CI solutions, there are several options.

trans-unit.source: This document will cover two very popular ones, [TravisCI](https://travis-ci.org/) and [AppVeyor](https://www.appveyor.com/).
trans-unit.target: This document will cover two very popular ones, [TravisCI](https://travis-ci.org/) and [AppVeyor](https://www.appveyor.com/).

trans-unit.source: There are, of course, many other services out there, but the installation and usage mechanisms should be similar.
trans-unit.target: There are, of course, many other services out there, but the installation and usage mechanisms should be similar.

trans-unit.source: Installation options for CI build servers
trans-unit.target: Installation options for CI build servers

trans-unit.source: Using the native installers
trans-unit.target: Using the native installers

trans-unit.source: If using installers that require administrative privileges is not something that presents a problem, native installers for each platform can be used to set up the build server.
trans-unit.target: If using installers that require administrative privileges is not something that presents a problem, native installers for each platform can be used to set up the build server.

trans-unit.source: This approach, especially in the case of Linux build servers, has one advantage which is automatic installing of dependencies needed for the SDK to run.
trans-unit.target: This approach, especially in the case of Linux build servers, has one advantage which is automatic installing of dependencies needed for the SDK to run.

trans-unit.source: The native installers will also install a system-wide version of the SDK, which may be desired; if it's not, you should look into the [installer script usage](#using-the-installer-script) outlined below.
trans-unit.target: The native installers will also install a system-wide version of the SDK, which may be desired; if it's not, you should look into the [installer script usage](#using-the-installer-script) outlined below.

trans-unit.source: Using this approach is simple.
trans-unit.target: Using this approach is simple.

trans-unit.source: For Linux, there is a choice of using a feed-based package manager, such as `apt-get` for Ubuntu or `yum` for CentOS, or using the packages themselves (that is, DEB or RPM).
trans-unit.target: For Linux, there is a choice of using a feed-based package manager, such as `apt-get` for Ubuntu or `yum` for CentOS, or using the packages themselves (that is, DEB or RPM).

trans-unit.source: The former would require setting up the feed that contains the packages.
trans-unit.target: The former would require setting up the feed that contains the packages.

trans-unit.source: For Windows platforms, you can use the MSI.
trans-unit.target: For Windows platforms, you can use the MSI.

trans-unit.source: All of the binaries can be found on the [.NET Core getting started page](https://aka.ms/dotnetcoregs) which points to the latest stable releases.
trans-unit.target: All of the binaries can be found on the [.NET Core getting started page](https://aka.ms/dotnetcoregs) which points to the latest stable releases.

trans-unit.source: If you wish to use newer (and potentially unstable) releases or the latest, you can use the links from the [CLI repo](https://github.com/dotnet/cli).
trans-unit.target: If you wish to use newer (and potentially unstable) releases or the latest, you can use the links from the [CLI repo](https://github.com/dotnet/cli).

trans-unit.source: Using the installer script
trans-unit.target: Using the installer script

trans-unit.source: Using the installer script allows for non-administrative installation on your build server.
trans-unit.target: Using the installer script allows for non-administrative installation on your build server.

trans-unit.source: It also allows a very easy automation.
trans-unit.target: It also allows a very easy automation.

trans-unit.source: The script itself will download the ZIP/tarball files needed and will unpack them; it will also add the install location on the local machine to the PATH so that the tools become available for invocation immediately post-install.
trans-unit.target: The script itself will download the ZIP/tarball files needed and will unpack them; it will also add the install location on the local machine to the PATH so that the tools become available for invocation immediately post-install.

trans-unit.source: The installer script can easily be automated at the start of the build to fetch and install the needed version of the SDK.
trans-unit.target: The installer script can easily be automated at the start of the build to fetch and install the needed version of the SDK.

trans-unit.source: The "needed version" is whatever version application being built requires.
trans-unit.target: The "needed version" is whatever version application being built requires.

trans-unit.source: You can choose the installation path so you can install the SDK locally and then clean up after the build completes.
trans-unit.target: You can choose the installation path so you can install the SDK locally and then clean up after the build completes.

trans-unit.source: This brings additional encapsulation and atomicity to the build process.
trans-unit.target: This brings additional encapsulation and atomicity to the build process.

trans-unit.source: The installation script reference can be found in the [dotnet-install](dotnet-install-script.md) document.
trans-unit.target: The installation script reference can be found in the [dotnet-install](dotnet-install-script.md) document.

trans-unit.source: Dealing with the dependencies
trans-unit.target: Dealing with the dependencies

trans-unit.source: Using the installer script means that the native dependencies are not installed automatically and that you have to install them if the operating system you are installing on already doesn't have them.
trans-unit.target: Using the installer script means that the native dependencies are not installed automatically and that you have to install them if the operating system you are installing on already doesn't have them.

trans-unit.source: You can see the list of prerequisites in the [CLI repo](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/master/Documentation/prereqs.md).
trans-unit.target: You can see the list of prerequisites in the [CLI repo](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/master/Documentation/prereqs.md).

trans-unit.target: CI services setup examples

trans-unit.target: The below sections show examples of configurations using the mentioned CI SaaS offerings.

trans-unit.source: AppVeyor
trans-unit.target: AppVeyor

trans-unit.source: The [appveyor.com ci](https://www.appveyor.com/) has .NET Core SDK preview1 already installed in the build worker image
trans-unit.target: The [appveyor.com ci](https://www.appveyor.com/) has .NET Core SDK preview1 already installed in the build worker image

trans-unit.source: Just use:
trans-unit.target: Just use:

trans-unit.source: It's possible to install a specific version of .NET Core SDK, see [example appveyor.yml](https://github.com/dotnet/core-docs/blob/master/appveyor.yml) for more info.
trans-unit.target: It's possible to install a specific version of .NET Core SDK, see [example appveyor.yml](https://github.com/dotnet/core-docs/blob/master/appveyor.yml) for more info.

trans-unit.source: In the example, the .NET Core SDK binaries are downloaded, unzipped in a subdirectory and added to `PATH` env var.
trans-unit.target: In the example, the .NET Core SDK binaries are downloaded, unzipped in a subdirectory and added to `PATH` env var.

trans-unit.source: A build matrix can be added to run integration tests with multiple version of the .NET Core SDK.
trans-unit.target: A build matrix can be added to run integration tests with multiple version of the .NET Core SDK.
